greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: If the numbers 1 to n^3 are arranged in a cubic array, a(n) is the minimum number of primes in each row of the n^2 rows in the "east-west view" that can have primes.
comment: This is a three-dimensional generalization of A083382.
reference: See A083382 for references and links to the two-dimensional case.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..900
example: For the case n=3, the numbers are arranged in a cubic array as follows:
The first row is (1,2,3), the second is (4,5,6), etc. Surprisingly, a(n) = 0 for all n from 3 to 66. It appears that a(n) > 0 for n > 128. This has been confirmed up to n = 1000.
mathematica: Table[minP=n; Do[s=0; Do[If[PrimeQ[n*(c-1)+r], s++ ], {r, n}]; minP=Min[s, minP], {c, n^2}]; minP, {n, 100}]
program: (PARI) A084928(n) = { my(m=-1); for(i=0,(n^2)-1,my(s=sum(j=(i*n),((i+1)*n)-1,isprime(1+j))); if((m<0) || (s < m), m = s)); (m); }; \\ _Antti Karttunen_, Jan 01 2019
xref: Cf. A083382, A083414, A084927 (top view), A084929 (north-south view).
results.author: _T. D. Noe_, Jun 12 2003
